Investing in new tech, talent, and products; programmatic M&A; and decarbonization.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fadvanced%20electronics%2Four%20insights%2Feuropean%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation%2Feuropean-machinery-companies-achieving-balance-through-innovation.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="european-machinery-companies-achieving-balance-through-innovation" data-layer-report-name="european-machinery-companies-achieving-balance-through-innovation>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (11 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>The European machinery sector </strong>continues to operate within an uncertain and volatile macroeconomic environment characterized by the ongoing war in Ukraine, the resulting energy crisis, and persistent supply chain challenges. Some companies have fared better than others. Our research suggests companies that weathered the crisis of 2020 were able to solidify their advantages, emerge stronger than before, and deliver sustained growth in the subsequent two years.</p>
<p>The road ahead offers both new challenges and new opportunities for the machinery industry. A solid order intake for the future indicates continued demand for machinery products and services. However, profitability is again under pressure, largely because inflation is raising material costs and consequently the cost of goods sold.</p>
<p>To stay competitive, European machinery companies will need to address the growing labor shortage by attracting, developing, and retaining skilled talent. They will also need to spur technological innovation at scale and at pace, decarbonize, and shift toward sustainable energy sources. A programmatic M&A strategy can advance these efforts, enable the digitalization needed to implement improvements, and support integrated solutions and services to unlock potential recurring revenue streams and create additional value for customers and companies alike.</p>
<h2>The state of the industry: A regional perspective</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the research</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is based on data from the 2023 McKinsey Machinery Benchmark, which has been collecting data from more than 100 European machinery companies since 2013. Extracted and double-checked from verified sources such as annual reports, the high-quality data in the benchmark includes all major income-statement and balance-sheet items, selected cash-flow elements, and data points such as head counts and share prices.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>McKinsey’s Machinery Benchmark finds that across multiple financial and operational metrics, European machinery companies are on a slower trajectory than their North American counterparts (see sidebar “About the research”). Despite strong revenue growth, the European sector has lagged behind in margin growth, M&A activity, and productivity (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex1-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Revenue development has been similar across regions, but European companies have lagged behind their North American peers in profitability since 2016." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex1-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h3>Steady revenue growth across regions</h3>
<p>European and North American machinery companies have continued a revenue growth trajectory following the initial disruption of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. Revenues in the European sector increased by roughly 18 percent in 2022, while the North American sector’s annual revenue grew at a stable but much more modest 7 percent.</p>
<h3>European EBIT margins continuing to lag behind North American</h3>
<p>While both regions experienced strong margin recovery in 2021, the two regions diverged, slightly but significantly, in 2022. In Europe, EBIT margins fell by roughly 1.3 percentage points to around 8.6 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e7d87523-79bd-4c7e-8100-f18af9e2035b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e7d87523-79bd-4c7e-8100-f18af9e2035b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Henry Legge, Fabian Newger, Thorsten Schleyer, and Ville Väliaho, “<a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/the-ascent-of-nordic-companies-in-the-global-machinery-market">The ascent of Nordic companies in the global machinery market</a>,” McKinsey, April 21, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> In North America, companies experienced a slightly smaller decline of around 0.7 percentage points but sustained strong EBIT margins around 10.4 percent. The drop in EBIT margins for both regions was roughly half of the drop that occurred during the initial COVID-19 disruptions in 2020.</p>
<p>Only 40 percent of the companies in our benchmark managed to improve their margins in 2022, and about three-quarters of these same companies also delivered margin improvements in 2021. This suggests that companies that successfully bounced back from the immediate aftermath of the pandemic were able to sustain profitable growth through 2022. We expect this trend to continue, and to affect European and North American players equally.</p>
<h3>A link between M&A activity and margin performance?</h3>
<p>After a sharp drop in the second half of 2020 following the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, M&A and divestiture activity rebounded within a year (Exhibit 2). At times, M&A and divestiture activity has even surpassed prepandemic levels, with more than 50 mergers and acquisitions recorded during some quarters in 2021 and 2022. A closer look at the regional distribution reveals a correlation between M&A activity and margin performance. In particular, the Nordic countries and North America have a similar rate of M&A activity and, as discussed in the foregoing section of this article, a similar upward trajectory in margin development. This suggests that continuous M&A supports margin resilience. Divestitures, on the other hand, have no obvious link to geographic regions. The North American companies in our benchmark lead on divestitures for the most part, with the highest share among their peers. This suggests a greater openness toward divestitures in North America and a tendency to protect the core business in Europe.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex2-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Following a sharp decline in 2020, M&A activity in the machinery sector surpassed prepandemic levels in 2021 and 2022." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex2-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Variations in inventory stockpiles</h3>
<p>North American inventory ratios remain stable around 19 percent, but a decline of inventory stockpiles is expected by the end of 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="92a4beb8-ab25-4c34-8b4c-f4e4b2aa0486"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="92a4beb8-ab25-4c34-8b4c-f4e4b2aa0486" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">NAM Manufacturers’ Outlook Survey: Second Quarter 2023, National Association of Manufacturers, June 7, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> European players, on the other hand, continued to build up their inventories, reaching an average of almost 23 percent in 2022—an increase of around two percentage points. This is the highest inventory ratio since 2015, the year we began tracking this metric.</p>
<h3>Good news on productivity across the industry</h3>
<p>Average productivity in the European machinery sector increased by almost 10 percent from 2021 to 2022, following an 8 percent increase during the previous year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4ab82ea6-758c-4217-a747-c901791f1b6b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4ab82ea6-758c-4217-a747-c901791f1b6b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Productivity measured in revenue per full-time-equivalent employee (FTE).</span></span></span></a></span> Less than 10 percent of the firms in our benchmark reported a decline in productivity. North American players also reported strong productivity growth of 9.5 percent, on the heels of 9.0 percent growth in the previous year. This is a positive development for both regions, especially in light of ongoing labor shortages, and affirms that they have the capacity to overcome production delays and avoid order backlogs.</p>
<h3>Order backlogs across regions</h3>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Spotlight on the German machinery sector</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>German machinery players delivered strong revenue growth of 13 percent from 2021 to 2022.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f846be88-90f8-49b3-87d5-2378f054dc32"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f846be88-90f8-49b3-87d5-2378f054dc32" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Machinery Benchmark, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> However, EBIT margins fell by 0.6 percentage points, following a significant recovery in the previous year. Rising costs are likely responsible for the margin pressure: cost of goods sold increased to 70.5 percent, on average, an increase of nearly 0.5 percentage points from 2021. The average material cost ratio (as a share of revenue) also increased by nearly one percentage point to 49.5 percent in the same period. Average SG&A costs, on the other hand, declined below prepandemic levels to slightly less than 16 percent. Meanwhile, R&D ratio (an indicator of innovation activity) declined to roughly 4 percent in 2022, suggesting that innovation has ramped down in the past year.</p>
<p>The inventory ratio for German machinery companies increased for the fifth year in a row, likely in response to persistent supply chain disruptions facing the global economy. Now that current inventory ratios have reached more than 23 percent, the industry can turn toward other levers, such as production process design, to build resilience and future-proof German companies.</p>
<p>The business climate for German machinery and equipment manufacturing declined by 5.5 balance points in March and again by 11.9 balance points in June 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a3266b65-42f4-4174-b129-a3b5d9be1694"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a3266b65-42f4-4174-b129-a3b5d9be1694" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>ifo Konjunkturperspektiven</em> 06/23, ifo Institut, 2023; <em>ifo Konjunkturperspektiven</em> 03/23, ifo Institut, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Business expectations for the next six months dropped further by almost 20 balance points to –21 balance points. In March there was a significant improvement of expectations, registered by an increase of 15.2 points to a slightly negative balance point of –2.0.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="802e2baf-8ff8-4295-a3d9-7c9eb20f5505"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="802e2baf-8ff8-4295-a3d9-7c9eb20f5505" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>ifo Konjunkturperspektiven</em> 03/23, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Despite the increase in productivity for machinery players in the benchmark, order backlogs have continued to increase (Exhibit 3). The rise in incoming orders after a pandemic-related drop in orders led to a spike in backlog, which was exacerbated by labor and supply shortages. The German machinery industry’s order backlog began to rise in 2020 and reached an all-time high in late 2022. By April 2023, order intake had dropped significantly, by 25 percent, similar to the drop experienced during the pandemic. Though this drop will temporarily help ease the backlog, the long-term solution is to mitigate Germany’s labor shortage (see sidebar “Spotlight on the German machinery sector”).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex3-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Order backlogs in Germany reached a historic high in late 2022 and are now stable at about 12 months." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex3-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Advancing labor, innovation, and decarbonization: The road ahead</h2>
<p>Increasing the supply of qualified skilled labor is essential to the future of manufacturing in Europe. Automation continues to displace workers in some sectors and heighten the need for machinery workers trained to operate, service, and optimize robots and other advanced technology. The rising pressure to innovate in what is becoming an increasingly commoditized market means machinery players must compete for tech talent. And, as efforts to achieve net-zero targets intensify, companies must equip themselves to not only lower their operating emissions but also contribute low- and zero-carbon products and services.</p>
<h3>A widening labor gap</h3>
<p>The global manufacturing sector continues to grapple with a widespread labor shortage. In the European region, the number of open jobs rose by approximately 70 percent between 2020 and 2022.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e0e04ecd-818a-4532-a9b7-c286c762da31"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e0e04ecd-818a-4532-a9b7-c286c762da31" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The time frame refers to the fourth quarter of 2020 to the fourth quarter 2022. See “Job vacancy statistics by NACE Rev. 2 activity - quarterly data (from 2001 onwards),” Eurostat, accessed June 15, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Since the beginning of 2022, this number has hovered slightly above 500,000 vacancies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9626db12-f105-4842-ab02-570e731a40e9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9626db12-f105-4842-ab02-570e731a40e9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The time frame refers to the fourth quarter of 2020 to the fourth quarter 2022. See “Job vacancy statistics by NACE Rev. 2 activity - quarterly data (from 2001 onwards),” Eurostat, accessed June 15, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The German machinery sector alone had approximately 250,000 vacancies in 2022—an increase of more than 100 percent from the previous year. Despite the staggering demand, the number of young people in Germany without the minimum education required for many career paths remained stable at 6 percent from 2011 to 2021 (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4ba11595-5fbe-4c63-b222-a45dd342c62e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4ba11595-5fbe-4c63-b222-a45dd342c62e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The German <em>Hauptschulabschluss</em> is a school-leaving certificate obtained after completing the <em>Hauptschule</em>, a type of secondary school in Germany. It signifies the completion of a secondary education program that emphasizes practical and vocational skills. It is the minimum qualification required for many entry-level jobs and vocational training programs and serves as a foundation for further education or career paths.</span></span></span></a></span> This labor shortage has significant implications for the future of the sector, which requires a highly skilled workforce to operate and innovate at pace. Manufacturing vacancies as a share of total vacancies in Germany also increased between 2020 and 2022, rising by more than ten percentage points from an already high share of 38 percent to almost 50 percent.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex4-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="As skilled machinery job vacancies in Germany skyrocket, the number of young Germans lacking minimum education remains stagnant." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex4-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The vacancy situation in Europe varies significantly by country. For instance, in the Czech Republic, the country with the second-highest number of manufacturing vacancies, the absolute vacancy level remained stable between 2020 and 2022, leading to a decrease in the relative share of vacancies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d962710-3e70-4b0c-b5e9-afd16ae4ea1c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d962710-3e70-4b0c-b5e9-afd16ae4ea1c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The absolute vacancy level is raw number of vacancies in the country and the relative share is the share of vacancies in the country relative to overall sum of job vacancies in Europe. “Job vacancy statistics,” accessed June 15, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> This means that the Czech Republic can acquire talent for open positions while continuing to grow.</p>
<p>Education and training programs can help address the shortage of skilled workers in the machinery sector, improve the quality of products and services, and spur economic growth and development. In particular, machinery companies and associations can experiment with specialized programs to recruit and integrate workers without traditional educational credentials, who represent an untapped source of potential talent.</p>
<h3>Leaning in on R&D to lead innovation</h3>
<!-- -->
<p>Europe’s wave of innovation continued in 2022. After a slight decline over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic, the number of patent applications submitted to the European Patent Office (EPO) increased by more than 2.5 percent to more than 193,000—surpassing the record set the previous year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a9c6aecd-058e-4449-9c14-c098923b63d8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a9c6aecd-058e-4449-9c14-c098923b63d8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Record demand for European patents,” Patent Index 2022, European Patent Office, accessed August 9, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> However, the overall number of patents granted by the EPO fell to 81,754, leaving many submitted innovations unrecognized and unprotected.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bc5d6e10-9138-4a6d-9da5-d531122258db"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bc5d6e10-9138-4a6d-9da5-d531122258db" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Patent Index 2022: Granted patents,” European Patent Office, updated March 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> No country in our benchmark maintained its pre-2022 level of granted patents.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3eb38e59-4cb6-4e72-afa7-708ba074364d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3eb38e59-4cb6-4e72-afa7-708ba074364d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Patent Index 2022: Granted patents,” European Patent Office, updated March 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Of the top ten countries, China’s decline in granted patents was the smallest at around 15 percent, while Japan’s decline was the largest, at almost 30 percent.</p>
<p>While Germany remains the second-largest patent initiator in Europe (in absolute numbers), its share of patents fell by 4.7 percent between 2021 and 2022,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e1f5756-267f-4a7c-bec8-072df8faa5d2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e1f5756-267f-4a7c-bec8-072df8faa5d2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Patent Index 2022: Statistics at a glance</em>, European Patent Office, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> and its R&D ratio has fallen each year since 2020. Some European regions, such as the Nordics and Switzerland, maintained a steady R&D ratio during the same period.</p>
<p>In the United States, the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 includes provisions to expand domestic manufacturing capacity by encouraging investment; boost purchases of critical supplies from domestic or free-trade partners; and advance R&D and deployment for carbon capture and storage (CCUS), clean hydrogen, and other innovative climate technologies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="43b897c2-ebbc-4ff2-80af-48ab90c3340e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="43b897c2-ebbc-4ff2-80af-48ab90c3340e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-inflation-reduction-act-heres-whats-in-it">The Inflation Reduction Act: Here’s what’s in it</a>,” McKinsey, October 24, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> To maintain their competitive edge in innovation, Germany machinery players should reevaluate their current R&D strategies, especially as growing labor and energy costs place them at a disadvantage relative to companies in other regions.</p>
<p>Globally, the number of patents for specialized machines decreased by 1.8 percent in 2022.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b902ffb0-e254-464c-a9c6-0fadd8fa6d44"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b902ffb0-e254-464c-a9c6-0fadd8fa6d44" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Patent Index 2022</em>, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The Nordic countries of Sweden, Denmark, and Finland rank in the top five in our benchmark for the number of patent applications as a share of population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="da670d63-6681-4887-a576-bb66bb38af6d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="da670d63-6681-4887-a576-bb66bb38af6d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Patent Index 2022</em>, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Switzerland remains the undisputed leader, with more than twice as many applications as second-ranked Sweden.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="85a4f356-3fc1-4f16-95f6-36e447ce1a79"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="85a4f356-3fc1-4f16-95f6-36e447ce1a79" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Patent applications per million inhabitants 2022,” European Patent Office, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Trends in Europe have been promising, but patent issue growth in the past decade has been inconsistent. Only China and Denmark have experienced stable growth in the number of issued patents across all major sectors (Exhibit 5). This trend is particularly concerning for Germany, where average growth in the number of patents issued has remained low in most machinery categories, with the exception of handling and other machines. China, on the other hand, has experienced high growth in all categories except textiles, machine tools, and paper machinery.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex5-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="China and Denmark are the only countries that have experienced stable growth in the number of patents issued across all major machinery sectors." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex5-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Because the labor shortage is the bottleneck for the machinery industry’s output, companies remain focused on securing talent as well as seeking opportunities to automate production. The digital space, meanwhile, remains largely untapped, despite its potential to help create value and new revenue streams.</p>
<p>Innovation will be a strategic differentiating factor for European companies in the future as companies based in regions with lower operating costs continue to improve on product quality metrics.</p>
<h3>Accelerating sustainability efforts</h3>
<p>Along with raw materials, energy is a vital input to production in the machinery sector. Every process, from forming and forging to milling, is energy intensive. Because of the complexity and variety of parts in machines, the cumulative energy demand is considerable. Given the push toward decarbonization, access to sustainable energy is poised to become a key differentiator in the next few years.</p>
<p>European countries rank first in the world for share of sustainable energy relative to total energy production.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="86a4f706-6997-4c3e-9880-265c9b1576b7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="86a4f706-6997-4c3e-9880-265c9b1576b7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Includes electricity generation from hydro, wind, solar, geothermal, other renewables, and combustible renewables.</span></span></span></a></span> Within Europe, Norway and Denmark lead, generating 98.6 percent and 85.8 percent of their energy from renewable sources, respectively, followed by Sweden at 63.2 percent, Finland at 59.8 percent, and Switzerland at 59.1 percent. In contrast, China has a roughly 27 percent renewable-energy share, and the United States trails at 22 percent (Exhibit 6).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex6-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Europe leads the world in renewable energy as a share of total energy production, while the United States lags behind." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex6-f.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The adoption of sustainable production is a necessary step across all industries to meet 2050 net-zero-emissions targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b341d2f7-6de2-4b00-b256-414be7012d10"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b341d2f7-6de2-4b00-b256-414be7012d10" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<em><a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/nature-in-the-balance-what-companies-can-do-to-restore-natural-capital">Nature in the balance: What companies can do to restore natural capital</a></em>,” McKinsey, December 5, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Sustainability not only provides a reputation boost for companies that offer low-carbon products but can also improve quality across all products in a portfolio. This long-term trend toward product improvement can in turn support the opportunity for price premiums and more resilient margins in the future.</p>
<p>As machinery and industrial companies embrace science-based targets and make bold net-zero commitments, reducing carbon emissions becomes a nearer-term endeavor (Exhibit 7). Machinery leaders need to incorporate a sustainability perspective into their strategic decisions about sourcing parts or about where production facilities should be located.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 7</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex7-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="As of 2022, more than 4,000 companies worldwide have set or committed to science-based targets." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/advanced%20electronics/our%20insights/european%20machinery%20companies%20achieving%20balance%20through%20innovation/svgz-european-machinery-companies-ex7-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Boosting the value of European machinery through programmatic M&A</h2>
<p>As mentioned previously, M&A activity correlates with margin improvements. And McKinsey empirical research analyzing 20 years of data has shown that programmatic M&A, compared with other approaches to M&A, carries significantly lower risk and is more likely to enhance performance.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e37739ef-5363-4a47-92c2-3e1ea131d25f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e37739ef-5363-4a47-92c2-3e1ea131d25f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-one-approach-to-m-and-a-is-more-likely-to-create-value-than-all-others">How one approach to M&A is more likely to create value than all others</a>,” <em>McKinsey Quarterly</em>, October 13, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Programmatic M&A strategy is organized around a central business case or theme and involves acquiring meaningful total market capitalization through at least three deals each year.</p>
<p>European leaders will need to leverage programmatic M&A to form partnerships that close the capability gap and keep the machinery sector on the leading edge of technological innovation. They must also invest in innovation governance and capabilities at scale and at pace. This means implementing agile practices and customer-centric approaches to manage high-risk, long-term projects. Companies will need to raise or reallocate funds for long-term innovation and business development on a larger scale than ever before. And just as important, they will need to build the skills and the capabilities to innovate.</p>
<p>The European machinery sector cannot afford to lag behind on innovation. A 2022 McKinsey Global Institute analysis revealed that Europe leads on only two of ten transversal technologies—technologies that span sectors—that will shape the global competitive landscape of the future.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f473d20e-1d7b-47a8-bf16-93f71fa2d1ee"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f473d20e-1d7b-47a8-bf16-93f71fa2d1ee" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<em><a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/securing-europes-competitiveness-addressing-its-technology-gap">Securing Europe’s competitiveness: Addressing its technology gap</a></em>,” McKinsey, September 22, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> These technologies are characterized by their relevance across all major sectors in terms of their disruptive potential and include applied AI, distributed infrastructure, next-generation computing, and bio revolution. European machinery companies will need to invest in transversal technology sectors such as next-level process automation and the future of connectivity to become global technology leaders in the decades ahead.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="618108a2-23bd-4b78-9fa1-519e19cb1dbe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="618108a2-23bd-4b78-9fa1-519e19cb1dbe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<em><a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/securing-europes-competitiveness-addressing-its-technology-gap">Securing Europe’s competitiveness: Addressing its technology gap</a></em>,” McKinsey, September 22, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Partnerships with technology organizations and experts not only address the machinery sector’s shortage of transversal technology skills but also provide a competitive edge in attracting skilled labor. These collaborations enable more efficient digitalization as well as access to external knowledge and expertise, ensuring sustained competitiveness in the ever-evolving digital economy. Additionally, such partnerships play a crucial role in driving innovation toward decarbonization of machinery products, leading to significant reductions in emissions (Scopes 1, 2, and 3) across both the machinery sector and the industries it serves. Engaging low-carbon and carbon-neutral companies in regions rich in renewable energy sources may soon become a higher priority than labor and other operating costs.</p>
<p>Programmatic M&A can help to scale and expand the core business and can succeed even under seemingly adverse conditions. As McKinsey has outlined elsewhere, there are four approaches to deploying programmatic M&A.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a763aff-7d42-4bd0-ae88-5f41828f6881"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a763aff-7d42-4bd0-ae88-5f41828f6881" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Markus Berger-de León, Paul Jenkins, Jerome Königsfeld, and Lukas Salomon, “<a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/buy-and-scale-how-incumbents-can-use-m-and-a-to-grow-new-businesses">Buy and scale: How incumbents can use M&A to grow new businesses</a>,” McKinsey, December 21, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Machinery companies can yield considerable benefit by applying these approaches:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong>Technology-driven acquisition.</strong> These types of acquisitions focus on securing patents and technological capabilities as well as on creating digital innovations to improve existing products.</li>
    <li><strong>Acqui-hiring.</strong> The key objectives for these acquisitions are to help mitigate the industry’s skilled labor shortage and to save time and costs associated with training and hiring.</li>
    <li><strong>Product expansion.</strong> These acquisitions have dual benefits: expanding an existing ecosystem to realize synergies and immediate growth in revenue and the customer base.</li>
    <li><strong>Regional expansion.</strong> This type of acquisition typically focuses on a similar product or service offering that provides access to local market knowledge. Leveraging the existing structure, customers, and value chain accelerates market entry.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>Labor shortages and global economic volatility notwithstanding, European machinery players have options available to address present challenges while strengthening the entire sector for the long term. Investments in education, training, new products, and renewable energy can help them realize fundamental, global goals of expanding the employment pipeline and achieving net-zero emissions. Companies that deploy such investments strategically, bolstering them with programmatic M&A, can fast-track innovation and forge new paths to growth.</p></div><div European countries move the needle as the labor shortage worsens and inflation and costs rise? Investing in new tech, talent, and products; programmatic M\u0026A; and decarbonization."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Machinery mergers and acquisitions in Europe and investing in tech, talent, products, and decarbonization, can help countries innovate amid the labor shortage."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-09-06T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe European machinery sector \u003c/strong\u003econtinues to operate within an uncertain and volatile macroeconomic environment characterized by the ongoing war in Ukraine, the resulting energy crisis, and persistent supply chain challenges. Some companies have fared better than others. Our research suggests companies that weathered the crisis of 2020 were able to solidify their advantages, emerge stronger than before, and deliver sustained growth in the subsequent two years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe road ahead offers both new challenges and new opportunities for the machinery industry. A solid order intake for the future indicates continued demand for machinery products and services. However, profitability is again under pressure, largely because inflation is raising material costs and consequently the cost of goods sold.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo stay competitive, European machinery companies will need to address the growing labor shortage by attracting, developing, and retaining skilled talent. They will also need to spur technological innovation at scale and at pace, decarbonize, and shift toward sustainable energy sources. A programmatic M\u0026amp;A strategy can advance these efforts, enable the digitalization needed to implement improvements, and support integrated solutions and services to unlock potential recurring revenue streams and create additional value for customers and companies alike.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe state of the industry: A regional perspective\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Machinery Benchmark finds that across multiple financial and operational metrics, European machinery companies are on a slower trajectory than their North American counterparts (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;About the research\u0026rdquo;). Despite strong revenue growth, the European sector has lagged behind in margin growth, M\u0026amp;A activity, and productivity (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eSteady revenue growth across regions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEuropean and North American machinery companies have continued a revenue growth trajectory following the initial disruption of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. Revenues in the European sector increased by roughly 18 percent in 2022, while the North American sector\u0026rsquo;s annual revenue grew at a stable but much more modest 7 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEuropean EBIT margins continuing to lag behind North American\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile both regions experienced strong margin recovery in 2021, the two regions diverged, slightly but significantly, in 2022. In Europe, EBIT margins fell by roughly 1.3 percentage points to around 8.6 percent.[[footnote 1]] In North America, companies experienced a slightly smaller decline of around 0.7 percentage points but sustained strong EBIT margins around 10.4 percent. The drop in EBIT margins for both regions was roughly half of the drop that occurred during the initial COVID-19 disruptions in 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnly 40 percent of the companies in our benchmark managed to improve their margins in 2022, and about three-quarters of these same companies also delivered margin improvements in 2021. This suggests that companies that successfully bounced back from the immediate aftermath of the pandemic were able to sustain profitable growth through 2022. We expect this trend to continue, and to affect European and North American players equally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eA link between M\u0026amp;A activity and margin performance?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter a sharp drop in the second half of 2020 following the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, M\u0026amp;A and divestiture activity rebounded within a year (Exhibit 2). At times, M\u0026amp;A and divestiture activity has even surpassed prepandemic levels, with more than 50 mergers and acquisitions recorded during some quarters in 2021 and 2022. A closer look at the regional distribution reveals a correlation between M\u0026amp;A activity and margin performance. In particular, the Nordic countries and North America have a similar rate of M\u0026amp;A activity and, as discussed in the foregoing section of this article, a similar upward trajectory in margin development. This suggests that continuous M\u0026amp;A supports margin resilience. Divestitures, on the other hand, have no obvious link to geographic regions. The North American companies in our benchmark lead on divestitures for the most part, with the highest share among their peers. This suggests a greater openness toward divestitures in North America and a tendency to protect the core business in Europe.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003eVariations in inventory stockpiles\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNorth American inventory ratios remain stable around 19 percent, but a decline of inventory stockpiles is expected by the end of 2023.[[footnote 2]] European players, on the other hand, continued to build up their inventories, reaching an average of almost 23 percent in 2022\u0026mdash;an increase of around two percentage points. This is the highest inventory ratio since 2015, the year we began tracking this metric.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGood news on productivity across the industry\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAverage productivity in the European machinery sector increased by almost 10 percent from 2021 to 2022, following an 8 percent increase during the previous year.[[footnote 3]] Less than 10 percent of the firms in our benchmark reported a decline in productivity. North American players also reported strong productivity growth of 9.5 percent, on the heels of 9.0 percent growth in the previous year. This is a positive development for both regions, especially in light of ongoing labor shortages, and affirms that they have the capacity to overcome production delays and avoid order backlogs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOrder backlogs across regions\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the increase in productivity for machinery players in the benchmark, order backlogs have continued to increase (Exhibit 3). The rise in incoming orders after a pandemic-related drop in orders led to a spike in backlog, which was exacerbated by labor and supply shortages. The German machinery industry\u0026rsquo;s order backlog began to rise in 2020 and reached an all-time high in late 2022. By April 2023, order intake had dropped significantly, by 25 percent, similar to the drop experienced during the pandemic. Though this drop will temporarily help ease the backlog, the long-term solution is to mitigate Germany\u0026rsquo;s labor shortage (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Spotlight on the German machinery sector\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch2\u003eAdvancing labor, innovation, and decarbonization: The road ahead\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIncreasing the supply of qualified skilled labor is essential to the future of manufacturing in Europe. Automation continues to displace workers in some sectors and heighten the need for machinery workers trained to operate, service, and optimize robots and other advanced technology. The rising pressure to innovate in what is becoming an increasingly commoditized market means machinery players must compete for tech talent. And, as efforts to achieve net-zero targets intensify, companies must equip themselves to not only lower their operating emissions but also contribute low- and zero-carbon products and services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eA widening labor gap\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe global manufacturing sector continues to grapple with a widespread labor shortage. In the European region, the number of open jobs rose by approximately 70 percent between 2020 and 2022.[[footnote 4]] Since the beginning of 2022, this number has hovered slightly above 500,000 vacancies.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe German machinery sector alone had approximately 250,000 vacancies in 2022\u0026mdash;an increase of more than 100 percent from the previous year. Despite the staggering demand, the number of young people in Germany without the minimum education required for many career paths remained stable at 6 percent from 2011 to 2021 (Exhibit 4).[[footnote 6]] This labor shortage has significant implications for the future of the sector, which requires a highly skilled workforce to operate and innovate at pace. Manufacturing vacancies as a share of total vacancies in Germany also increased between 2020 and 2022, rising by more than ten percentage points from an already high share of 38 percent to almost 50 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe vacancy situation in Europe varies significantly by country. For instance, in the Czech Republic, the country with the second-highest number of manufacturing vacancies, the absolute vacancy level remained stable between 2020 and 2022, leading to a decrease in the relative share of vacancies.[[footnote 7]] This means that the Czech Republic can acquire talent for open positions while continuing to grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEducation and training programs can help address the shortage of skilled workers in the machinery sector, improve the quality of products and services, and spur economic growth and development. In particular, machinery companies and associations can experiment with specialized programs to recruit and integrate workers without traditional educational credentials, who represent an untapped source of potential talent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLeaning in on R\u0026amp;D to lead innovation\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eEurope\u0026rsquo;s wave of innovation continued in 2022. After a slight decline over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic, the number of patent applications submitted to the European Patent Office (EPO) increased by more than 2.5 percent to more than 193,000\u0026mdash;surpassing the record set the previous year.[[footnote 8]] However, the overall number of patents granted by the EPO fell to 81,754, leaving many submitted innovations unrecognized and unprotected.[[footnote 9]] No country in our benchmark maintained its pre-2022 level of granted patents.[[footnote 10]] Of the top ten countries, China\u0026rsquo;s decline in granted patents was the smallest at around 15 percent, while Japan\u0026rsquo;s decline was the largest, at almost 30 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile Germany remains the second-largest patent initiator in Europe (in absolute numbers), its share of patents fell by 4.7 percent between 2021 and 2022,[[footnote 11]] and its R\u0026amp;D ratio has fallen each year since 2020. Some European regions, such as the Nordics and Switzerland, maintained a steady R\u0026amp;D ratio during the same period.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 includes provisions to expand domestic manufacturing capacity by encouraging investment; boost purchases of critical supplies from domestic or free-trade partners; and advance R\u0026amp;D and deployment for carbon capture and storage (CCUS), clean hydrogen, and other innovative climate technologies.[[footnote 12]] To maintain their competitive edge in innovation, Germany machinery players should reevaluate their current R\u0026amp;D strategies, especially as growing labor and energy costs place them at a disadvantage relative to companies in other regions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGlobally, the number of patents for specialized machines decreased by 1.8 percent in 2022.[[footnote 13]] The Nordic countries of Sweden, Denmark, and Finland rank in the top five in our benchmark for the number of patent applications as a share of population.[[footnote 14]] Switzerland remains the undisputed leader, with more than twice as many applications as second-ranked Sweden.[[footnote 15]] Trends in Europe have been promising, but patent issue growth in the past decade has been inconsistent. Only China and Denmark have experienced stable growth in the number of issued patents across all major sectors (Exhibit 5). This trend is particularly concerning for Germany, where average growth in the number of patents issued has remained low in most machinery categories, with the exception of handling and other machines. China, on the other hand, has experienced high growth in all categories except textiles, machine tools, and paper machinery.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eBecause the labor shortage is the bottleneck for the machinery industry\u0026rsquo;s output, companies remain focused on securing talent as well as seeking opportunities to automate production. The digital space, meanwhile, remains largely untapped, despite its potential to help create value and new revenue streams.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInnovation will be a strategic differentiating factor for European companies in the future as companies based in regions with lower operating costs continue to improve on product quality metrics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAccelerating sustainability efforts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong with raw materials, energy is a vital input to production in the machinery sector. Every process, from forming and forging to milling, is energy intensive. Because of the complexity and variety of parts in machines, the cumulative energy demand is considerable. Given the push toward decarbonization, access to sustainable energy is poised to become a key differentiator in the next few years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEuropean countries rank first in the world for share of sustainable energy relative to total energy production.[[footnote 16]] Within Europe, Norway and Denmark lead, generating 98.6 percent and 85.8 percent of their energy from renewable sources, respectively, followed by Sweden at 63.2 percent, Finland at 59.8 percent, and Switzerland at 59.1 percent. In contrast, China has a roughly 27 percent renewable-energy share, and the United States trails at 22 percent (Exhibit 6).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe adoption of sustainable production is a necessary step across all industries to meet 2050 net-zero-emissions targets.[[footnote 17]] Sustainability not only provides a reputation boost for companies that offer low-carbon products but can also improve quality across all products in a portfolio. This long-term trend toward product improvement can in turn support the opportunity for price premiums and more resilient margins in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs machinery and industrial companies embrace science-based targets and make bold net-zero commitments, reducing carbon emissions becomes a nearer-term endeavor (Exhibit 7). Machinery leaders need to incorporate a sustainability perspective into their strategic decisions about sourcing parts or about where production facilities should be located.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 7]]\n\u003ch2\u003eBoosting the value of European machinery through programmatic M\u0026amp;A\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs mentioned previously, M\u0026amp;A activity correlates with margin improvements. And McKinsey empirical research analyzing 20 years of data has shown that programmatic M\u0026amp;A, compared with other approaches to M\u0026amp;A, carries significantly lower risk and is more likely to enhance performance.[[footnote 18]] Programmatic M\u0026amp;A strategy is organized around a central business case or theme and involves acquiring meaningful total market capitalization through at least three deals each year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEuropean leaders will need to leverage programmatic M\u0026amp;A to form partnerships that close the capability gap and keep the machinery sector on the leading edge of technological innovation. They must also invest in innovation governance and capabilities at scale and at pace. This means implementing agile practices and customer-centric approaches to manage high-risk, long-term projects. Companies will need to raise or reallocate funds for long-term innovation and business development on a larger scale than ever before. And just as important, they will need to build the skills and the capabilities to innovate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European machinery sector cannot afford to lag behind on innovation. A 2022 McKinsey Global Institute analysis revealed that Europe leads on only two of ten transversal technologies\u0026mdash;technologies that span sectors\u0026mdash;that will shape the global competitive landscape of the future.[[footnote 19]] These technologies are characterized by their relevance across all major sectors in terms of their disruptive potential and include applied AI, distributed infrastructure, next-generation computing, and bio revolution. European machinery companies will need to invest in transversal technology sectors such as next-level process automation and the future of connectivity to become global technology leaders in the decades ahead.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePartnerships with technology organizations and experts not only address the machinery sector\u0026rsquo;s shortage of transversal technology skills but also provide a competitive edge in attracting skilled labor. These collaborations enable more efficient digitalization as well as access to external knowledge and expertise, ensuring sustained competitiveness in the ever-evolving digital economy. Additionally, such partnerships play a crucial role in driving innovation toward decarbonization of machinery products, leading to significant reductions in emissions (Scopes 1, 2, and 3) across both the machinery sector and the industries it serves. Engaging low-carbon and carbon-neutral companies in regions rich in renewable energy sources may soon become a higher priority than labor and other operating costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProgrammatic M\u0026amp;A can help to scale and expand the core business and can succeed even under seemingly adverse conditions. As McKinsey has outlined elsewhere, there are four approaches to deploying programmatic M\u0026amp;A.[[footnote 21]] Machinery companies can yield considerable benefit by applying these approaches:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTechnology-driven acquisition.\u003c/strong\u003e These types of acquisitions focus on securing patents and technological capabilities as well as on creating digital innovations to improve existing products.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAcqui-hiring.\u003c/strong\u003e The key objectives for these acquisitions are to help mitigate the industry\u0026rsquo;s skilled labor shortage and to save time and costs associated with training and hiring.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eProduct expansion.\u003c/strong\u003e These acquisitions have dual benefits: expanding an existing ecosystem to realize synergies and immediate growth in revenue and the customer base.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRegional expansion.\u003c/strong\u003e This type of acquisition typically focuses on a similar product or service offering that provides access to local market knowledge. Leveraging the existing structure, customers, and value chain accelerates market entry.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLabor shortages and global economic volatility notwithstanding, European machinery players have options available to address present challenges while strengthening the entire sector for the long term. Investments in education, training, new products, and renewable energy can help them realize fundamental, global goals of expanding the employment pipeline and achieving net-zero emissions. Companies that deploy such investments strategically, bolstering them with programmatic M\u0026amp;A, can fast-track innovation and forge new paths to growth.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-09-06T10:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHenry Legge, Fabian Newger, Thorsten Schleyer, and Ville V\u0026auml;liaho, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/the-ascent-of-nordic-companies-in-the-global-machinery-market\"\u003eThe ascent of Nordic companies in the global machinery market\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, April 21, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eNAM Manufacturers\u0026rsquo; Outlook Survey: Second Quarter 2023, National Association of Manufacturers, June 7, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eProductivity measured in revenue per full-time-equivalent employee (FTE).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe time frame refers to the fourth quarter of 2020 to the fourth quarter 2022. Rising costs are likely responsible for the margin pressure: cost of goods sold increased to 70.5 percent, on average, an increase of nearly 0.5 percentage points from 2021. The average material cost ratio (as a share of revenue) also increased by nearly one percentage point to 49.5 percent in the same period. Average SG\u0026A costs, on the other hand, declined below prepandemic levels to slightly less than 16 percent. Meanwhile, R\u0026D ratio (an indicator of innovation activity) declined to roughly 4 percent in 2022, suggesting that innovation has ramped down in the past year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe inventory ratio for German machinery companies increased for the fifth year in a row, likely in response to persistent supply chain disruptions facing the global economy. Now that current inventory ratios have reached more than 23 percent, the industry can turn toward other levers, such as production process design, to build resilience and future-proof German companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe business climate for German machinery and equipment manufacturing declined by 5.5 balance points in March and again by 11.9 balance points in June 2023.[[footnote 2]] Business expectations for the next six months dropped further by almost 20 balance points to –21 balance points.
